docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON - Some immediate benefits from the health care legislation advancing on Capitol Hill will ease the minds of parents who may have hit up against limitations of their existing health insurance.

headline.main: Health Bill Benefits for the Impatient

docs.abstract: Some immediate benefits from the health care legislation advancing on Capitol Hill will ease the minds of parents who may have hit up against limitations of their existing health insurance.
docs.snippet: Some immediate benefits from the health care legislation advancing on Capitol Hill will ease the minds of parents who may have hit up against limitations of their existing health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some immediate benefits from the health care legislation advancing on Capitol Hill will ease the minds of parents who may have hit up against limitations of their existing health insurance. Within six months, the Senate bill approved last week would allow dependent, unmarried children to remain on their parents' policies until their 26th birthday; the House bill would allow an additional year of dependent coverage, until the 27th birthday. Right now it varies from state to state.

headline.main: Health Bill Benefits For the Impatient
headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Some benefits from health care legislation on Capitol Hill will take effect with passage, like extended coverage for adult children; other major provisions will not be instituted for several years although new taxes and fees to help pay for them kick in much sooner; Democrats respond to Republican criticism with list of 'immediate deliverables,' which include patient protections and closing of Medicare 'doughnut hole'; list (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Inducing sleep with drugs near the end of life is a widely used treatment even as it vexes families and doctors.

headline.main: Hard Choice for a Comfortable Death: Sedation
headline.print_headline: Hard Choice for a Comfortable Death: Drug-Induced Sleep

docs.snippet: Inducing sleep with drugs near the end of life is a widely used treatment even as it vexes families and doctors.

docs.lead_paragraph: In almost every room people were sleeping, but not like babies. This was not the carefree sleep that would restore them to rise and shine for another day. It was the sleep before -- and sometimes until -- death. In some of the rooms in the hospice unit at Franklin Hospital, in Valley Stream on Long Island, the patients were sleeping because their organs were shutting down, the natural process of death by disease. But at least one patient had been rendered unconscious by strong drugs.

headline.main: Hard Choice for a Comfortable Death: Drug-Induced Sleep

docs.abstract: Article in series Months to Live discusses widely used practice of palliative or terminal sedation for terminally ill patients; doctors say practice is based on carefully thought-out ethical principles in which goal is never to end life, but to make patients more comfortable; practice may hasten death, and some critics to regard it as slow form of euthanasia; most families feel they and their doctors are doing right thing; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The vote clears the way for negotiations with the House, which passed a broadly similar bill last month, bringing Democrats a step closer to a goal they have pursued for decades.

headline.main: Senate Passes Health Care Overhaul on Party-Line Vote
headline.sub: Democrats United, but No Republican Votes for Measure
headline.print_headline: SENATE APPROVES HEALTH CARE BILL IN PARTY-LINE VOTE

docs.snippet: The vote clears the way for negotiations with the House, which passed a broadly similar bill last month, bringing Democrats a step closer to a goal they have pursued for decades.

docs.lead_paragraph: Updates | 8:01 a.m. This news article is being frequently updated on the Times Web site. The original news story, posted at 7:16 a.m., appears below.
docs.abstract: The Senate, voting early on Christmas Eve, approved landmark legislation to overhaul the nation's health care system.
docs.snippet: The Senate, voting early on Christmas Eve, approved landmark legislation to overhaul the nation's health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: Here's my prediction for the Next Big Thing in health care: chronotherapy, or therapy by the clock. Yes, in the future, your medicines, your operations, your mealtimes and when you step onto the treadmill or the badminton court - all will be overseen by your personal chronoconsultant.
docs.abstract: Getting in sync with one's circadian rhythm might be a key to good health across the board.
docs.snippet: Getting in sync with one's circadian rhythm might be a key to good health across the board.
